title: Between 12 August 2019 and 30 November 2019, will Russia and Iran conduct any joint naval exercises in the Strait of Hormuz?
preds: About 1/5 of a month left, reducing it to 0%.
Between 12 August 2019 and 30 November 2019, will Russia and Iran conduct any joint naval exercises in the Strait of Hormuz? Late to this party.
It's increasingly looking like the comments made towards this eventuality was just more bellicose rhetoric and saber rattling.
-20%. Not much news on this recently and time is short.
civil unrest in Iran and preoccupation of the US administration make it increasingly unlikely that either side will escalate in the near term.
Updating for the time left: I originally estimated a 6% for two months, now there are 2/3 of a month left.
Dropping to zero because there isn't much time left.

I'm not aware of any announcement, much less the planning needed for a true joint exercise in the Indian Ocean/Gulf of Oman
Like I wrote back in August - they could do joint-exercise-lite by re-flagging a couple of Iranian attack boats, man them with Russian crews, and call that a joint exercise.
So I keep a 1% chance of "something" happening before month end.

There has been no announcement of a joint exercise that will take place in Nov.  A joint exercise would need significant advertisement and coordination to ensure the exercise does not escalate into a conflict.  Additionally, with Turkey invading Syria, Russia is tied up at the moment with the military and political ramifications of Turkey's actions.  Mr. Trump is tied up in impeachment tweets and doesn't have time to continue to poke and provoke Iran into wanting to hold the exercises. China has not indicated it wants to hurry any naval exercises along which could show they only tentatively support the exercises.  Too many obstacles to overcome in the next 26 days to hold a joint exercise.  Hardly likely to occur in 2019 at all.

With one month left before the close of this time window and current high tensions in the region, it seems unlikely that Russo-Iranian military cooperation will manifest in overt naval exercises in the Strait of Hormuz by 30 November. However, there are numerous signs that point to probable future cooperation in the maritime space. Many have already raised an MOU signed July 2019 between the Russian Federation and Iranian Navies - which seems to suggest at least the plausibility of joint Russian-Iranian naval exercises. Given the nature of the Iranian fleet as a littoral defense force and Russia's increased demonstrations of their 'blue water' capabilities, it seems very likely Russian naval presence in the region will grow (a number of Russian warships have transversed the Suez canal in the past three years for stated anti-piracy reasons among other things)  A few other factors worth considering:
- would a joint Iranian-Russian exercise risk antagonizing the U.S. following its partial withdrawal from Syria?
- Status of Russo-Turkish relations vis-a-vis Iran?
- potential for Saudi or Gulf escalation following previous attacks  Bottom line: Russian-Iranian joint naval exercises are likely on the horizon (22% in the next 9 months) but very unlikely during the next 30-odd days.
Still unlikely, it would be rushed if it did occur
Trump is signaling that there no consequences for Turkey. Other countries to follow.
Lowering probability since the development situation in Syria
Russia is focused on Turkey / Syria. Russia would like to be seen as peacemakers / kingmakers in the region

https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3029819/china-russia-iran-plan-joint-naval-drill-international-waters
https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2019/10/2/syria-russia-and-iran-conduct-first-joint-military-exercise But will it be in the Strait of Hormuz....
Very unlikely that Russia will engage into such an exercise since forces focus on Syria and Russia. waters.

Putin tries to offer a counter to American pronouncements. Their support to Iran and Syria rests on the show they put up, to curtail Americsn adventurism should Trump be provoked into something by Turkey.
Joint military exercise is not planned in the Strait of Hormuz, rather in Sea of Oman or Indian Ocean.

There has been no inter-country naval drills in the strait of Hormuz in the recent past. As a strategically important strait, conducting a naval drill here will send the wrong signal all around the world. The move will be seen as too provocative/aggressive.
absence of any information . . . Wouldn't the purpose of such an exercise be to impress other countries?  So wouldn't they want a lot of PR?  Yet, there is nothing.

Second hand reporting of a Tasnim news agency release says a joint naval drill with Russia and China is being planned for the Gulf of Oman and the northern part of the Indian Ocean.
No timeline was released.
There was a specific negation of any intention to hold these drills in the Persian Gulf.
However, when I went to the Tasmin site - no such story came up.
Nevertheless, Gulf of Oman is not the Strait of Hormuz.
So reduce the likelihood of this possibility still further.
Russia, Iran, and China’s power come from the threat of action, or intimidation of smaller and larger countries. See “mother in law” power as defined by political theorist Hans Morgenthau.
Not much time left till 30 Nov.
Going lower because planning exercises takes time and I haven't seen the evidence that Russia in particular is rushing to do this.
Cannot see Russia making such a strategic mistake. Information seems to be coming only from Iran side. If Russia was making this type of commitment -maybe, but no can not see it this year.

It was announces in July with no follow ups from either side since then. The news seems to come from Iran side only and I did no see confirmation from Russian side anywhere. There was no dates/years mentioned. Earlier this year Iran also announces naval exercises  in Caspian Sea, which have not happened yet either.
Possible but not much likely to occur.
Economically, these countries can't afford an impressive naval exercise.
Reading the comments from @Anneinak and a previous analysis from @Kitsonj, I am inclined to reduce the probability a bit further, from 9% to 6%, a factor of 2/3 of my previous probability.

This seems less likely to happen at all than it did in August, and recent accounts also mention doing the exercises in the Gulf of Oman instead of the Straight of Hormuz, lowering the probability even further.

I have reduced the probability from 22 to 9%. Reasons: (i) the previous 22% was an average between a log-normal distribution (6 months average, "log(6-4)" variance) and a constant probability in time from here to the Iranian new year, yielding a 33%, (ii) if we notice that if we assume that the total probability of exercises from here till the Iranian new year is not necessarily a 100%, but maybe a 50%, the previous 33% will transform into a 16.5%, coinciding with the log-normal distribution, which means that my previous 22% anchor was too high, (iii) the Chinese apparently have some interest to joint, according to the Iranians, though China-based military analyst doubt that the involvement will be serious (might be limited to anti-piracy operations), (iv) the involvement of the Chinese might, if anything, complicate the coordination, (v) right now, after the attack to Saudi Arabia, probably there is no a great interest to hold the maritime exercises soon. Instead it will better to wait till things have calmed down and then throw the media-bomb of the joint naval exercises. (i) and (ii) stand for the "outside-view", to which I finally assign a 16%, while (iii), (iv) and (v) are the "inside view", which should be accounted for by a multiplier, maybe 3/4 each, yielding then (9/16) x 16% = 9%.
The US is still weak vs Russia and Putin so I can see them getting this done before he gets voted out.
No benefit for Russia at this time.

https://www.newsweek.com/iran-russia-china-military-support-ties-1460850 "Iran has sought wider international partnerships in countering President Donald Trump's self-styled "maximum pressure" campaign against the Islamic republic, looking especially for more help from the U.S.' two top competitors, Russia and China. General Ghadir Nezami Pour, chief of international affairs and defense diplomacy for the Iranian military's general staff, told the country's Mosalas magazine Saturday that Iran has "begun joint exercises with other countries, and for the first time since the Islamic Revolution, we will hold joint naval exercises with Russia and China as the two major powers in the northern Indian Ocean and the Oman Sea." . . .
. . . 
. . .  Moscow and Tehran . . . [signed] a memorandum of understanding to deepen their naval ties in July. At that ceremony, Iranian naval commander Rear Admiral Hossein Khanzadi first revealed plans for joint Iran-Russia navy drills in the northern Indian Ocean. Earlier this month, Zarif confirmed the reports, adding that "maybe other countries will also be interested in joining these drills," as quoted by the state-run Tass Russian News Agency. Moscow has not confirmed its participation in such maneuvers, but already worked alongside Tehran in Syria. . . . 
. . . 
Asked Monday about Beijing's potential involvement in upcoming exercises with Tehran and Moscow, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Geng Shuang offered a vague response, telling a news briefing only that "the Chinese armed forces maintain normal exchange and cooperation with armed forces of other countries." He referred reporters to the Chinese military, which has yet to release any information regarding the exercises. Jacopo Scita, an H.H. Sheikh Nasser al-Mohammad al-Sabah doctoral fellow at Durham University's School of Government and International Affairs, pointed out "that the news of the possible joint navy drill came from Iranian sources and has not been reported or confirmed by Chinese and Russian state media," though he did note that "an Iranian high-profile military delegation visited China in the past weeks, where they were invited to visit a marine base and navy facilities in Shanghai." "It is quite obvious that Chinese and Iranian officials discussed military cooperation, technologies, and even future joint drills. However, I believe it is unlikely that such a drill will happen soon, especially given the very sensitive moment in the Persian Gulf," Scita told Newsweek. "China has always been very careful to balance its position between Iran and Saudi Arabia and, in the aftermath of the Aramco attack, a major naval exercise with Iran and Russia in the Sea of Oman will send a message not attuned to Beijing's usual posture." "The impression is that Iran is really trying to picture its relationships with Russia and China stronger than what they actually are," he explained, calling it part of "an Iranian attempt to put pressure on both the U.S., dismissing the idea that 'maximum pressure' is isolating Iran, and on Russia and China too, in the attempt of pushing the two countries to support Iran more openly and actively." Farhad Rezaei, an Iran-focused defense and security analyst based in Ottawa, told Newsweek that "Iran probably wants to send multiple messages." "First, to show that its has the support of China and Russia if attacked by the United States, especially since this announcement comes at a time when Washington declared it would send more forces and missile defense capabilities to Saudi Arabia (following the strikes on the Aramco oil facilities, which was attributed to Iran)," he explained. "Second, Iran also tries to reassert its presence in the waters with help of the Chinese and Russians especially since the announcement of the drill coincides with Washington's declaration that it is forming a naval mission with the other regional countries including Saudi Arabia and UAE." Like Scita, however, he noted that "there are a number of issues that should be taken into consideration" when it came to speculation about a growing axis among Iran, Russia and China.
. . . 
"First, China and Russia are also partners of Saudi Arabia and Israel as well, and they are not happy with Iran's harassing of the kingdom and its verbal attack on Israel," Rezaei told Newsweek. "Second, the Chinese are not happy with Iran's actions in the waters and its alleged attack on Aramco, because that will cause a remarkable increase in the oil price."
~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I note that they mention the Gulf of Oman, not the Strait of Hormuz, and that doubts are being expressed about how soon the naval exercise will occur.

Iran and Russia have had naval exercises in the past in the Caspian Sea. Reports state that Russia and Iran have been planning naval exercises in the region again. Russia will continue to want to engage with its allies in the Middle East however not at the cost of intervention from the US. Especially given recent oil attacks on Saudi Arabia. Statements made that Iran will have exercises in the the Gulf of oman have been made, whether they will go through the strait of Hormuz and before the 30th of November

With US's declining hegemony in Middle East, don't think Russia want to jeopardize its chances of expanding its relationship with middle east. Nothing to win in Russia's case, even china's so called military drills with iran and russia are largely reduced to outside activites such as anti piracy, not willing to risk China's relationship with the middle east, due to its heavy reliance on oil. Russia is heavily reliant on middle east for the expansion of its exports and development of nuclear power. Russia's relationship with Iran's adversaries have all been rather good in the last 6 months or so.

In recent weeks, news on this issue has become far less dominant (or just insufficient space left on news channels and papers).  In recent weeks it feels more like a squeeze and tease mentality at play - cat and mouse.  Unless something drastic happens that encourages any of the major players to make a strike, then I don't see such naval exercises taking place in the near future.

Iran, Russia and China Plan Joint Naval Drill in Gulf of Oman Thanks to @kbynum & @KitsonJ  for this reference on the probability
*****
Iran's General Staff, Ghadir Nezami (2019) stated that:  “Iran has no intention of holding the drill within the Persian Gulf” (Para. 3).
*** The Maritime Executive (2019) Sept. 23, stated that: Iran says that it is planning a joint naval drill with Russia and China in the Gulf of Oman and the Indian Ocean, according to semi-official news agency Tasnim (Para.1). Under ordinary circumstances, a naval exercise among three partner nations would be unremarkable. However, tensions between the United States and Iran are unusually high, and Russian and Chinese forces are the U.S. military's primary identified competitors. The United States is leading a naval patrol coalition in the same region in order to deter a repeat of the attacks on six tankers off Fujairah earlier this year.  The head of foreign affairs for Iran's General Staff, Ghadir Nezami, told Tasnim that the joint drill will be held in the Gulf of Oman and the northern portion of the Indian Ocean. He added that Iran has no intention of holding the drill within the Persian Gulf. Nezami did not specify a timeline, but he did indicate that the exercise has "political goals" - namely, showing cooperation among the three partner nations (Para. 1-3). **
Reference ** The Maritime Executive Website. (2019). Iran, Russia and China Plan Joint Naval Drill in Gulf of Oman. The Maritime Executive. Sept. 23, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.maritime-executive.com/article/iran-russia-and-china-plan-joint-drill-in-gulf-of-oman
Recent reports that Iran has "no intention" of holding any exercises in Persian Gulf.
Just as a distraction from the election...

https://www.maritime-executive.com/article/iran-russia-and-china-plan-joint-drill-in-gulf-of-oman? No time given on this yet, but if they are planning the exercise in the Gulf of Oman, it wont be in the Straits of Hormuz

With the current tensions, Iran is unlikely to keep poking the US.  Although there is some possibility that this is used to create a distraction as both Russia and the US need to have people focus on something outside of domestic issues.
As the drills have been announced there would be some loss of face if the drills were not to go ahead.

Conflicting accounts and possible walk-backs by Iranian State news (https://www.newsweek.com/russia-iran-train-fight-back-us-1452689) made it seem like even odds the exercises even happened before next March (2020). Given the drone strikes on Saudi Oil, it is unlikely that the exercises will occur at all based on increasing tensions in the region. China will most likely not participate in exercises in the Persian Gulf because they have already walked back their involvement (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3030032/china-expected-send-anti-piracy-fleet-not-navy-joint-drill) and it seems as if Russia and Iran would not want to lose the support of China in joint exercises specifically in the Gulf.

A Year Later, Iran Finds Evaporating Sympathy at the U.N. Sanger and Fassihi (2019) Sept. 23, stated that: When Iran’s president and foreign minister arrived in New York a year ago for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, they were riding high. At news conferences and in television appearances, they cast President Trump as an untrustworthy deal-breaker, and European leaders largely sided with the pair in a desperate effort to preserve the 2015 nuclear agreement after the United States renounced it.
This year could not be more different. Suddenly, President Hassan Rouhani and his witty, often biting American-educated foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, are on the defensive. They are denying any Iranian involvement in the destruction of two major Saudi oil facilities, an assertion that even former Secretary of State John Kerry, who negotiated the nuclear accord four years ago and has become its biggest defender, finds far-fetched. Iran, he said, was behind the attack “one way or the other” (Para. 1-3). But “Iran has come to this year’s U.N.G.A. with a real wake-up call that what they are able to get from Europeans is no more than some limited political cover for support of the nuclear deal,” said Ellie Geranmayeh, the deputy head of Middle East and North Africa studies for the European Council on Foreign Relations (Para 7). Iranian officials, she said, have arrived in New York discovering that the Europeans cannot offer any substantive economic relief, and that even a French-led initiative to issue a credit line of $15 billion, essentially an advance payment on Iranian oil shipments, is likely to fail. Washington will most likely not issue waivers, and European banks are unwilling to join the effort if they believe they will be banned from clearing transactions in American dollars. Two weeks ago, it appeared that Iran might find a way out, taking Mr. Trump up on his offer of negotiations. But the attacks on Saudi Arabia, and the American accusations of Iranian involvement, have all but killed that possibility, American officials said (Para. 7-9). The hawkish Mr. Pompeo clearly senses that the attacks on the Saudi oil facilities, for which he blamed the Iranians before any forensic evidence had been gathered, have fundamentally changed the negotiating dynamics. He finally has the opportunity he has sought for 18 months: a chance to kill Europe’s effort to neutralize sanctions (Para. 17). Mr. Pompeo doubled down on his critique on Sunday, saying the Iranians are “bloodthirsty and looking for war,” and suggesting that as the sanctions cut deeper, the Iranian people will demand changes in their government — though he stopped just short of demanding regime change. “They’re operating today in five countries,” Mr. Pompeo said of the Iranians on Sunday on CBS News’s “Face the Nation.” “It’s expensive. They’ve already had to make difficult decisions about whether they’re going to feed their people, provide medicine to their people, or they’re going to launch missiles into Saudi Arabia” (Para. 17-19). Reference Sanger, D., E. & Fassihi, F. (2019). A Year Later, Iran Finds Evaporating Sympathy at the U.N. The New York Times. Middle East. Sept 23, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/23/world/middleeast/iran-un-rouhani.html ***** Karim, N. (2019). Iran asks West to leave Persian Gulf as tensions heightened. Associated Press. Military. Sept. 22, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.apnews.com/a7a19c8ca02c427c9316351e76cc1d12 *** Associated Press Website. (2019). Full Coverage Gulf Tensions. Associated Press. Military. Sept. 22, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.apnews.com/tag/PersianGulftensions
we know it will happen according to the Irans foreign ministry . when exactly not sure as our friends have suggested it needs to be programmed well in advance .

https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3029819/china-russia-iran-plan-joint-naval-drill-international-waters I'm reading vague reports that China may participate, too, and that the exercise might not be in the Strait of Hormuz, but in the Sea of Oman and northern Indian Ocean:  a 3rd nation complicates planning, and may delay it.   However, what I read suggests that the schedule may be pushed forward to counter DJT's threats. "There were no reports of the joint drill plan in Chinese state media.
Analysts said the exercise plausibly would let China show support for Iran.
“The timing of the joint exercise might be a bit sensitive and some might take it as a show of China’s support for Iran should there be any military conflicts between countries,” Beijing-based naval expert Li Jie said.
“But it might well be a regular military exchange between the countries if it is held in international waters and without targeting another country.”
Ni Lexiong, a military specialist and professor at Shanghai University of Political Science and Law, said the drill was to send the message that China would side with Iran “in extreme scenarios”.
China calls for calm in aftermath of drone strikes on Saudi oil facilities
“I don’t see things will go that far, but the navy drill is to send the intimidating message,” Ni said.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This question closes soon.  My understanding is that joint naval exercises take a long time to plan.

Approach:


1.	Context of the question:

"Earlier this week, Rear Admiral of the Iranian Navy Hossein Khanzadi confirmed prior reports that Tehran and Moscow have signed an agreement to hold joint Naval drills: "Earlier, we signed an agreement [on joint exercises] with Russia’s Armed Forces and the Russian Fleet’s command. Soon the preparations and maneuvers’ planning will start and they will be carried out this year.” 06/08/2019

From <https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/iran-and-russia-getting-ready-hold-joint-naval-drills-strait-hormuz-71661> 


Note that this is only a memorandum, with no binding character.


2.	History: have both countries ever conducted joint ops? Or combined ops? With what countries do they practice combined operations?

•	 In 2015, there was a joint naval ops in Azerbaijan. Iran lent their ships to a Russian exercise (+) https://tinyurl.com/y2jp6sqr Flotilla was very small, consisting of a destroyer and 2 missile carriers.
•	Last naval joint operation was in 2017 in the Caspian Sea. Recent time, both national leaders still in office (+).  Large flottilla with marine participation https://www.mei.edu/publications/irans-navy-launches-five-day-naval-drills-caspian-sea
•	Russia is scaling operations with non-Nato countries (+) https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/17/russia-conducts-tsentr-2019-military-exercises-with-china-and-india.html, including in the same drill space as Nato https://tinyurl.com/y62vwnrc. However, no operations were made outside their immediate influence zone (~)


3.	 What classifies as a naval combined operation? How many ships?  
 Apparently sending as little as 3 ships to Azerbaijan classifies as a joint naval operation. Any participation of Russian personnel in Iranian drills or vice versa will be classified as such.


4.	Why would they do it? How do both countries project their power?

•	Russia has not made any ops or drills in contested territory outside of their immediate proximity. That might change eventually of course.
Iran has been capturing tankers in Hormuz.

•	Given the context of the capture of the oil tankers, a joint exercise in hormuz would not be scandalous (+)


5.	What is the general geo-political situation?

US-Iran
It is my impression that Trump is currently easing out from the middle east and focusing on China (broadly speaking). The withdrawal from Syria and his position relating to the events after the houthi attack on the Saudi refining facilities suggests this is a main trait of the Trump administration.

Russia-Middle East
•	 Apart from some logistical and ground support, Russia is not interacting with the middle eastern front remotely as much as the media would have most people believe. For example, the S300 system sold to Syria is yet to be delivered, despite dire need of said system by their syrian "allies". This is probably to avoid interfering with Israeli interests. Russia has no interest in creating a conflict with Saudi Arabia -quite the contrary, as they would make an excelent weapons client for the russian military complex, and an convenient ally in future oil disruptions.
Russia-Saudi Arabia
	During 2017, Saudi Arabia encouraged the United States to remove sanctions on Russia pertaining to its activity in Ukraine in exchange for Russian assistance in ending the Iranian military presence in Syria.[48]
	Russia has remained neutral between Saudi Arabia and Qatar in the 2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis, offering to mediate in July 2017.[49]
	In December 2017, Russia withdrew diplomatic representation from the Houthi-held Yemeni capital Sana'a, in opposition to the killing of former Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh by the Houthis. The killing took place as a consequence of his defection from the Houthi-dominated Supreme Political Council to the Saudi coalition in the Yemeni Civil War.[50]
	From December 2017 onward, Saudi Arabia abandoned its past support for UN resolutions condemning the Russian military intervention in Ukraine, instead choosing to abstain.[51][52]
In August 2018, Russia backed Saudi Arabia in its dispute with Canada, with Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova stating that "the politicization of human rights matters is unacceptable".[53]
	In the aftermath of the assassination of Jamal Khashoggi in October 2018, Putin stated that Russia "cannot start deteriorating relations" with Saudi Arabia as "it did not know what really happened."[54] His press secretary, Dmitry Peskov, later added that there was "no reason basically not to believe" the official statements issued by Saudi Arabia on the matter.[55]
In December 2018, Russian deputy foreign minister Mikhail Bogdanov warned the United States against interference in the line of succession to the Saudi throne by pushing for the ouster of Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman, following reports that U.S. officials would support replacing him with Ahmed bin Abdulaziz.[56] Bogdanov stated that "the King made a decision and I can’t even imagine on what grounds someone in America will interfere in such an issue and think about who should rule Saudi Arabia, now or in the future."[57]

From <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations#Saudi_King's_visit_to_Russia_(October_2017)> 



Forecast:
No action. Given the context of Russian positive involvement with Saudi Arabia and Trump's desire to cool the middle eastern front, it is likely that operations that might trigger a strong-arm reaction from Trump will not be attempted. 20/09/2019 To be updated

Friday, September 20 (Para. 1). Trump says new sanctions on Iran President Donald Trump says his administration is imposing additional sanctions on Iran following last weekend's attack on Saudi oil facilities, which the administration has blamed on Iran. Speaking in the Oval Office on Friday during a meeting with Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison, Trump said, "We have just sanctioned the Iranian national bank"  (Para. 1-4). Monday, September 16 Iran seizes new boat near vital oil shipping lane Iran seized a boat suspected of being used to smuggle fuel and arrested its 11 crew members near a vital oil shipping lane, state TV reported on Monday (Para. 121). A naval patrol of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps intercepted the vessel carrying 250,000 litres of fuel near the Strait of Hormuz, state TV's website said, citing a commander of the force. "This boat was sailing from Bandar Lengeh towards United Arab Emirates waters before it was seized 32 kilometres east of Greater Tunb island," Brigadier General Ali Ozmayi was quoted as saying (Para. 121-123). ***

Updating due to increased events in area
Seems unlikely Putin would look to get involved.
-7% time lapse since last prediction. Hard to adjust based on current news flow and developments.

With only 10 weeks to go until 30 November, and the current drama in the Gulf, it seems very unlikely that Russia would be in any rush to provoke Saudi Arabia, Israel or the US by doing military exercises in such a strategic location.

Well, it's difficult to make a prediction. Naval exercises can happen really fast after announcement or might happen really late. There were announcements of joint exercises in the Caspian sea around January, which did not materialize yet and which are in principle unrelated to the Strait of Hormuz, but which might give a clue with regards to the expected delay. For the strait of Hormuz in June it was hope to happen in the following months or before the end of the Persian new year (March 20, 2020), not clear which one of the two. Now apparently the Russian navy will arrive for the end of the year. According to one source in some of the multiple news I was checking, Iran likes to hold naval exercises in autumn, but in 2019 they happen in February, in 2018 in August and in 2017 in March, but in 2016 maybe late summer / early autumn (have to check on this). This makes it difficult to find an anchor. From 2015-2017 there were several exercises with the Russians in the Caspian and in 2017 another one with the Chinese. There are a bit more than two months for the ending date of the question. If I assume a delay of 6 months, with a variance of 4 months, and make it into a log-normal distribution, this gives me a 16% probability. If I assume that they plan to do it before the Iranian new year with more or less the same probability for each month, this gives me a 33% probability. Together, this gives a 25%, but I don't trust the assumption of equal probability in time for the second case: I will weight the log-normal estimation with 2/3 and the uniform estimation with 1/3, giving a 22%. Then I will update in the following weeks according to the news.

It is important to note that no specific timeframe other than by the end of the year has been stipulated by either the Russians or Iranians, and the Iranians have little to gain from escalating tensions further with the current administration. Furthermore, the recent attacks on Saudi oil production further complicates the issue. While Yemen's Houthi's have claimed responsibility, Saudi Arabia's defense ministry has stated the attacks were sponsored by Iran, and Secretary of State Pompeo has blamed Iran and called the bombing an act of war. With tensions being as they are, I find it unlikely that Iran would choose to further provoke the US and its allies. Russia and Iran may conduct joint naval exercises in other parts of the Indian Ocean, but as of now it is unlikely they would do so in the Strait of Hormuz, baring provocation from the US or the Saudis. However, there is always room for miscalculation, and the Iranians could decide to use a show of force with Russia in response to US and Saudi action on the attack.
Increased chance Russia supports Iran here

Russian and Iran have signed an agreement to perform joint exercises in the Arabian Gulf but did not stipulate a timeframe.  This has prompted the US to engage allies, to include Israel, to support naval operations to ensure the Arabian Gulf remains open.  Russia and Iran have conducted joint exercises in the Caspian Sea but those waters are isolated and don't have a foreign presence.  To ratchet up exercises in the open waters of the Arabian Gulf that transports 20% of the world's oil is a very significant escalation.  Iran has agreed to allow Russia access to two of its ports as forward bases which will be a less provocative action than exercises.  Russia has also called upon UN security members to draft documents to prevent armed conflict in the Arabian Gulf signaling it does not have an appetite to create an actual armed conflict.
Given recent question over Iran’s involvement in the most recent terror attacks I don’t think thy will do anything additionally to directly provoke the US.
It would be too antagonistic and not benefit Russia to do so

Because I’m a pedant: ‘joint’ means more than one service (navy, army, Air Force, coast guard). You can’t have a ‘joint’ exercise with a single service. You *can* have a combined exercise if the forces of more than one nation are under a unified command. But even if that were to happen, I wouldn’t see such an exercise as ‘combined’ in any operationally significant  way, because Russia won’t submit its forces to Iranian command and not vice versa; and even of limited value to influence perceptions of the threat. And they’ve got a *long* way to sail to get any useful Russian naval forces to the Straits.

Pompeo blames Iran for drone attacks on Saudi oil field Kelly (2019) Sept. 15, stated that: Washington (CNN)Secretary of State Mike Pompeo pinned the blame on Iran for an attack at a Saudi oil field in a pair of tweets Saturday. Drone strikes on crucial Saudi Arabian oil facilities have disrupted about half of the kingdom's oil capacity, or 5% of the daily global oil supply, CNN Business reported earlier Saturday. Yemen's Houthi rebels took responsibility for the attacks but they are often backed by Iran.
But preliminary indications are that the attacks did not originate from Yemen and likely originated from Iraq, according to a source with knowledge of the incident. The same official said the damage was caused by an armed drone attack.
CNN National Security Analyst Peter Bergen said there have been more than 200 drone and missile attacks launched by Houthi rebels from Yemen into Saudi Arabia, and none have been as effective as Saturday's attack, lending credence to the belief that the attack did not originate from Yemen (Para. 1-4). At this point all Iran military activity reflects at least a foundation of communication and acknowledgement from Russia.  Additionally these two countries have ongoing joint naval exercises in the Caspian Sea etc...  EI15: Every Iranian Naval exercise is already joint with Russia at a certain level.  Bottom line: Nobody "practices" in the straights of Hormuz.  It is a "real world" tactical environment. Nobody goes there to train - it is the place for which they train.  They go there to prosecute tactical live-fire scenarios. It the hottest choke point on earth this summer.  If Russia and Iran jointly operate there it is potentially a deliberate live fire escalation between the US and Russia. Nobody (outside of the US CINC) is that stupid. It is further, a  stupid risk for Russia to bother using ships to force a military presence in the straights. Land based firepower on the Iran side would have a much sharper advantage and a much lower asset loss risk.   Russian ship(s) acting along side Iranian ones in the straight could be attacked, harmed or sunk by US/allies.  A Russian air defense missile truck on the other hand would require a US attack on Iranian soil. A legally irrefutable act of war. (Congress may have refused that option already this summer).  And it would technically be against an Iranian commanded asset not Russian.  If the Russians wanted to make a statement they would partner to emplace air defense capability on the Iranian side and then maybe shoot down am unmanned drone. 
Oh. They just did exactly that: https://www.globalresearch.ca/how-irans-soviet-era-air-defense-system-shot-down-americas-global-hawk-uav-over-strait-of-hormuz/5683697 If Trump starts  a war with, well it would be with everyone at this point, such a war will start in the straights of Hormuz in coming weeks.    If Putin wants a shooting war with the US or Britain etc.. he will start at 3am by removing Colorado Springs from the map,  not with a chain gun attack on the USS Boxer. In the end Putin will gladly train Iran to confront US vessels (and get paid with oil for the effort ) but his ships will be over the horizon during such encounters until America's Super power status erodes a little more on its own under Trump's strategic ineptitude.

This would seem to indicate a substantial commitment of Russian naval presence out from the near-abroad. However I see no Russian bases that can support Persian Gulf activity. The closest base, Tartus, seems to support only resupply ships. 
There has been reports of planned joint Indian Ocean exercises and joint Caspian Sea exercises. None yet have taken place. Both are safer for joint exercises, in terms of potential loss of equipment and life, than is the Strait - especially for navies that have never done joint exercises.
There are two Iranian naval bases outside of the Persian Gulf. It would seem small craft like fast-attack ships can use each. One is a deeper-water port capable of hosting destroyers. 
Based on info from cargo carriers, a trip from the Emirates to the Mediterranean takes 12 days - a proxy for what it would take to get from Tartus to those two outer IRGCN bases. 
Probabilities will be adjusted upward upon the two countries actually engaging in joint exercises in the Caspian Sea, or some activity in Tartus indicating a deployment from that base.
One way to obviate the need for actual Russian naval craft in the Gulf is to re-flag a couple of Iranian attack boats and have them manned  by Russian crews after they've trained on Iranian attack craft in the Caspian. This would be a low-budget and lower-risk alternative that would still support the headline banner of "joint naval exercises".

I went to look at how many previous naval exercises the Iranian and Russian navies have undertaken recently - one in 2017, one in 2015, but neither of these were held in the Strait of Hormuz, but in the Caspian sea. The Iranian and Chinese navies held an exercise in 2017 in the Strait and in 2014, and the Iranians have held yearly exercise under the name "noble/great prophet". (open to being wrong about this in case I have missed any). The Russians could potentially join in these exercises, but they are held in December typically. The Russian Navy is holding a naval exercise with the Indian Navy in December, using ships from the Pacific Fleet (https://thediplomat.com/2019/07/india-russia-military-exercise-indra-2019-to-take-place-in-december/) This could be what the Iranians mean when they say that the drills will take place this year. As @rjfmgy has pointed out, this announcement has been one sided, and we have not heard confirmation from the Russians that these exercises are taking place or that they will be taking place in the Strait. The Iranians have previously announced naval exercises that then didn't go ahead exactly as announced - the 2014 plan to deploy naval assets near the continental US maritime border. I then looked at the feasibility of getting Russian ships to an Iranian port. Back of the packet calculations, if departing from the Russian naval installation in Syria to Iran, its about 3200 nautical miles if travelling through the Seuz canal at 14 knots, and would take 9 days (https://sea-distances.org/). The newest Russian corvettes dont have the range for this, but the newest Russian frigate, the Admiral Gorshkov-class do have the range (and there could well be resupply ships travelling with them, and they could *potentially* refuel in the Chinese base in Djibouti, so I will take it that they can technically undertake the trip.) I haven't checked which ships would be available as I dont speak Russian or Iranian and the ship deployments are less public than those of the US or Royal Navy which are announced on twitter. Until we hear any more from the Russian side, or hear confirmation that any potential exercise will be held in the Strait of Hormuz, I don't think these will be happening in the time period.

I notice that all the news coverage of this - even the TASS story - only refers to the Iranian statement, with no corroboration by Moscow. Joint exercises in the Caspian Sea are not really comparable, since there is little possibility of international conflict in the Caspian Sea. Exercises in the Gulf would have an entirely different context and meaning. Russia's putative "security concept" for the Gulf seems to be careful not to take sides.  I really don't see any reason at all why Russia would undertake such an exercise. The Iranian-Russian "alliance" seems to be strictly a matter of convenience, and relates only to the war in Syria. Even in Syria, Iranian and Russian interests are far from identical. There is really no advantage for Russia (at least as far as I can see) to be perceived as partnering with Iran in the Gulf. I'll believe it when I see an independent Russian confirmation or a joint statement.
Naval Air ops certainly - but Ship to Ship...going 10% in case a Russian Vessel passes thru and they do something together.
They can make their points easier in other ways.
